deleted: In a May post on his blog, Trump amplified a false assertion by senate president Karen Fann that an "entire database" of Maricopa County voter information had been deleted. Maricopa County recorder Stephen Richer, a Republican who oversees elections, tweeted that Trump's post was "unhinged," noting he was looking at the database on his computer at that moment. Richer added, "We can’t indulge these insane lies any longer. As a party. As a state. As a country."<ref>

* {{Cite web|url=https://arizonadailyindependent.com/2021/05/12/deleted-election-files-and-ballot-handling-concerns-prompt-senate-president-to-beckon-maricopa-county-officials-to-state-capitol/|title=Deleted Election Files And Ballot Handling Concerns Prompt Senate President To Beckon Maricopa County Officials To State Capitol|first=Terri Jo|last=Neff|date=May 13, 2021}}

This is nonsense|first=Laurie|last=Roberts|website=The Arizona Republic}}</ref> The Maricopa county twitter account later tweeted a lengthy thread with the hashtag #RealAuditorsDont, citing examples including "Release false 'conclusions' without understanding what they are looking at" and "Hire known conspiracy theorists."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2021/05/17/maricopa-county-supervisors-plan-refute-election-auditors-claims/5121465001/|title=Maricopa County supervisors holding meeting Monday to refute election auditors' claims|first=Jen|last=Fifield|website=The Arizona Republic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Bump |first1=Philip |title=The fight that encapsulates the GOP’s struggle is happening in Arizona, not Washington |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/05/17/fight-that-encapsulates-gops-struggle-is-happening-arizona-not-washington/ |publisher=The Washington Post |date=May 17, 2021}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
added: Trump visited Arizona significantly more than his opponent, holding 4 rallies in just one week, compared to Biden, who only visited the state once.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/virus-outbreak-race-and-ethnicity-karen-pence-arizona-phoenix-731209930c60ff12f153fcf86d171982|title=Trump campaign in Arizona push with 4 visits this week|date=September 16, 2020|website=AP NEWS}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/10/08/joe-biden-presidential-campaign-kamala-harris-arizona-visit/5917484002/|title=Joe Biden and Kamala Harris meet tribal leaders, rally supporters in joint visit to Phoenix|author-first=Ronald J.|author-last=Hansen|author-first2=Andrew|author-last2=Oxford|website=The Arizona Republic}}</ref> Biden favored small, masked gathering to limit the spread of [[COVID-19]], which [[COVID-19 pandemic in the Navajo Nation|ravaged]] the state's large [[Navajo Nation|Navajo]] communities,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Klar|first=Rebecca|date=May 11, 2020|title=Navajo Nation reports more coronavirus cases per capita than any US state|url=https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/497091-navajo-nation-has-more-coronavirus-cases-per-capita-than-any-us-state|access-date=February 1, 2021|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref> whereas Trump favored large rallies with thousands of people in attendance, oftentimes without masks and contrary to the advice of health officials.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Giles|first=Ben|last2=Hernandez|first2=Rocio|date=October 29, 2020|title=Arizona Gov. Ducey Attends Trump Rallies Against State Health Director's Advice|url=https://kjzz.org/content/1631340/arizona-gov-ducey-attends-trump-rallies-against-state-health-directors-advice|access-date=|website=[[KJZZ-TV|KJZZ]]}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
added: Even after the election had come and gone, the [[Arizona Republican Party|Republican]]-majority [[Arizona Senate]] established a [[2021 Maricopa County presidential ballot audit|Maricopa County-based taxpayer-funded inquiry]] into the “voter fraud” alleged by the former President and his radical supporters. This audit took till September 2021 to be completed, and was considered something of a humiliation for its instigators because not only did it reaffirm there being no evidence of any voter irregularities, but it actually revealed Biden’s margin was larger than previously thought. <ref>{{Cite news|last=Schwartz|first=David|last2=Layne|first2=Nathan|date=2021-09-27|title='Truth is truth': Trump dealt blow as Republican-led Arizona audit reaffirms Biden win|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us/arizona-republicans-release-findings-widely-panned-election-audit-2021-09-24/|access-date=2021-09-28}}</ref> The audit revealed an additional 99 votes for Biden, and 261 less for Trump- increasing Biden’s victory by 360 votes.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Corse|first=Alexa|date=2021-09-25|title=Arizona GOP’s Election Audit Confirms Biden Win in State|language=en-US|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/arizona-gops-election-audit-confirms-biden-win-in-draft-report-11632467822|access-date=2021-09-28|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona

This audit took till September 2021 to be completed, and it changed the election results and Trump won all of Arizona's 11 electors.

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
added: ===Controversies===
====Early call====

[[Fox News]] called Arizona for Biden at 11:20 p.m. EST on November 3, election day, with 73% of projected vote counted.<ref>{{Cite web|author-last=Karni|author-first=Annie|date=November 4, 2020|title=Fox's Arizona call for Joe Biden flipped the mood at Trump campaign headquarters|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/nation-world/ct-nw-nyt-2020-election-arizona-results-20201105-26yhig5jq5curfj6xlwqjug6m4-story.html|access-date=|website=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author-first2=Maggie|author-last2=Haberman}}</ref>  The [[Associated Press]] did so at 2:51 a.m. EST on November 4.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=November 4, 2020|title=Breaking: Joe Biden wins Arizona. #APracecall at 12:51 a.m. MST. #Election2020|url=https://twitter.com/AP_Politics/status/1323895993142808576|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[Twitter]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Slodysko|first=Brian|date=2020-11-04|title=Explainer: Why AP called Arizona for Biden|url=https://apnews.com/article/ap-explains-arizona-joe-biden-bb16f91b04456b2513f40436248eb62d|access-date=November 5, 2020|website=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> Fox News received push-back from the Trump campaign as no other network called Arizona on election night.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Stratford|first=Michael|date=November 4, 2020|title=Fox News defends calling Arizona for Biden after pushback from Trump team|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/04/fox-news-arizona-election-2020-433997|access-date=|website=[[Politico]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Goodykoontz|first=Bill|date=November 4, 2020|title=Fox News second-guessed calling Arizona for Biden. It was 100% election night's best moment|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/media/2020/11/04/election-2020-fox-news-arizona/6157171002/|access-date=|website=[[The Arizona Republic]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Romero|first=Simon|date=2020-11-05|title=Trump Supporters Protest at Maricopa County Vote-Counting Site|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/04/us/politics/trump-supporters-protest-arizona.html|access-date=2021-02-03|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Izadi|first=Elahe|date=November 5, 2020|title=Who won Arizona? Why the call still differs by media organization.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/media/2020/11/04/fox-ap-arizona-biden/|access-date=|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> Fox News decision desk director [[Arnon Mishkin]] defended the Arizona call at 12:30 a.m., saying that Fox News was "four [[standard deviation]]s from being wrong"<ref name=":1" /> and that Trump was "not going to be able to take over and win enough votes to eliminate that seven-point lead that [Biden] has".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Peters|first=Justin|date=2020-11-04|title=Fox News' Arizona Call Drove Fox News Crazy|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/11/fox-news-arizona-call-trump.html|access-date=2020-11-30|website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]}}</ref> Biden and other Democratic candidates began election night with a wide lead in the state, and at the time Fox News called Arizona for Biden, he led by 210,259 votes (53.9% to 44.9%).<ref>{{Cite news|last=Montanaro|first=Domenico|date=November 19, 2020|title=AP Explains Calling Arizona For Biden Early, Before It Got Very Close|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/11/19/936739072/ap-explains-calling-arizona-for-biden-early-before-it-got-very-close|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[NPR]]}}</ref> The reporting in Arizona was the reverse of a '[[Blue shift (politics)|red mirage]]' and 'blue shift' effect seen nationwide, where the counting of election day votes before [[Early voting|early]] and [[Absentee ballot|absentee votes]] gave Republicans across the country an early lead. Votes cast on election day typically leaned heavily Republican while those cast early and absentee ballots leaned heavily Democratic, partially due to the skepticism of mail in voting mostly from Trump and fellow Republicans.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Kilgore|first=Ed|date=September 1, 2020|title=An Election Night 'Red Mirage' Is a Nightmare for Democrats|work=[[Intelligencer (website)|Intelligencer]]|publisher=[[MSN]]|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/an-election-night-red-mirage-is-a-nightmare-for-democrats/ar-BB18B4l3|access-date=February 2, 2021}}</ref> However, Arizona and several other [[Sun Belt]] states had the opposite effect. Early votes and absentee votes cast before the election were pre-counted and released shortly after 10:00 p.m. EST, when polls closed. Election day votes, as well as a few absentee votes, were released on election night and trickled in throughout the rest of the week. ''[[FiveThirtyEight]]'' correctly predicted that close races "might have to wait for those last few ballots before knowing who won".<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Rakich|first1=Nathaniel|last2=Mejía|first2=Elena|date=2020-10-30|others=Illustrations by David Huang|title=When To Expect Election Results In Every State|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-results-timing/|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[FiveThirtyEight]]}}</ref> Despite Biden's lead dropping throughout the week, it became clear that Trump's margin among election day votes would not be enough to overtake Biden's lead: Trump needed 59% of the outstanding vote to win,<ref>{{Cite tweet|title=We just got more than 70,000 votes in Maricopa County, Arizona, and Trump won them just 53% to 44%. We estimate there are about 171,000 ballots left to be counted in Arizona. If so, Trump would need to win 59% of them to overtake Biden.|user=FiveThirtyEight|number=1324897870881894400|access-date=February 2, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=November 7, 2020|title=Nearly 70,000 ballots in Arizona could change state of presidential race|work=Today Show|publisher=[[MSN]]|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/health/watch/nearly-70000-ballots-in-arizona-could-change-state-of-presidential-race/vp-BB1aMyQD|access-date=February 2, 2021}}</ref> but continuously won around only 53% of the votes released in several ballot dumps after election day.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Sandler|first=Rachel|date=November 6, 2020|title=Trump Whittles Biden's Lead In Arizona To Less Than 30,000 Votes|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rachelsandler/2020/11/06/trump-whittles-bidens-lead-in-arizona-to-less-than-30000-votes/|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[Forbes]]}}</ref>

On November 11, ''[[Decision Desk HQ]]'', along with several other outlets, projected that Biden would carry the state.<ref>{{Cite tweet |title=Decision Desk HQ Projects Biden (D) Has Won The State Of AZ And Its 11 Electoral Votes Race Called At 10:29 PM EST All Results: |user=decisiondeskhq |number=1326728894339309569 |date=November 12, 2020 |access-date=2020-11-12}}</ref> On November 12, [[ABC News]], [[NBC News]], [[CNN]] and ''[[The New York Times]]'' all projected Biden to carry the state shortly after 11:00 p.m. Eastern.<ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1327103935946100737|user=MaddowBlog|title=NBC News projects Joe Biden the winner of Arizona's 11 electoral votes. https://t.co/aU989NKymG|date=November 12, 2020|access-date=March 21, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1327107508209668097|user=CNN|title=CNN Projection: President-elect Joe Biden wins Arizona, widening his electoral vote lead over Donald Trump https://t.co/Ated1oWhS5 #CNNElection https://t.co/CTuL0eOHbB|date=November 12, 2020|access-date=March 21, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1327105259014000645|user=ByMikeBaker|title=The New York Times and CNN have both called Arizona for Biden, bringing his total to 290 electoral votes. Georgia and North Carolina remain. https://t.co/IQINLGkvLs https://t.co/TjuSqfDMLT|author=Mike Baker|date=November 12, 2020|access-date=March 21, 2021}}</ref>
==== Objection ====

On January 6, as a [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of Congress]] began to [[2021 United States Electoral College vote count|certify the election for President-elect Joe Biden and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris]], there was an objection to Arizona's 11 electoral votes, brought forward by Representative [[Paul Gosar]] of [[Arizona's 4th congressional district]] and Senator [[Ted Cruz]] of [[Texas]], and signed by 67 other senators and representatives.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=January 6, 2020|title=Objection to counting Arizona electoral votes|url=https://cdn.cnn.com/cnn/2021/images/01/06/objection.to.counting.arizona.electoral.votes.pdf|access-date=|website=[[CNN]]}}</ref> Debates began over the objection in the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] and [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], but were abruptly cut short after threats by pro-Trump demonstrators that escalated into a full blown [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|storming of the Capitol]], forcing the building to be locked down and Congress to be evacuated. After the Capitol was secured at 5:40 p.m.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=Meg|last2=Macaya|first2=Melissa|last3=Hayes|first3=Mike|last4=Mahtani|first4=Melissa|last5=Rocha|first5=Veronica|last6=Alfonso|first6=Fernado III|date=January 6, 2021|title=Rioters breach Capitol as Congress certifies Biden's win|work=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/congress-electoral-college-vote-count-2021/h_71a3aeeb0c13370d8d089e593c149fe8|url-status=live|access-date=February 2, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210106230938/https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/congress-electoral-college-vote-count-2021/h_71a3aeeb0c13370d8d089e593c149fe8|archive-date=January 6, 2021}}</ref> and Congress reconvened, the objection failed 6–93 in the Senate, and 121–303 in the House.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=January 6, 2021|title=Roll Call 10 Roll Call 10, MOTION, 117th Congress, 1st Session|url=https://clerk.house.gov/Votes/202110|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[Clerk of the United States House of Representatives|Office of the Clerk, U.S. House of Representatives]]}}</ref> The riot reportedly dissuaded several Republican senators and representatives from objecting to the Electoral College results.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Parks|first=Miles|date=January 6, 2021|title=Some Republican Senators Walk Back Objections To Election Results|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/congress-electoral-college-tally-live-updates/2021/01/06/954251826/some-republican-senators-begin-to-walk-back-objections-to-election-results|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=[[NPR]]}}</ref>
=== Lawsuits ===

{{Main|Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 United States presidential election from Arizona}}Following the election, [[Donald Trump]], the [[Arizona Republican Party]], [[Republican National Committee]], and several others filed lawsuits [[Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election|attempting to overturn the results]] of the election in Arizona, citing unsubstantiated claims of [[voter fraud]].
==== Overvotes lawsuit ====

On November 7, 2020, the Trump campaign, the [[Republican National Committee]], and the [[Arizona Republican Party]] filed a lawsuit against [[Secretary of State of Arizona|Secretary of State]] [[Katie Hobbs]] and [[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa County]] Recorder Adrian Fontes that alleged that [[overvote]]s were "incorrectly rejected". Overvotes occur when a voter mark more than the options allowed in a given race, and stray markings can often be processed as overvotes by tabulation machines. The machines are programmed to alert voters of the overvote, allowing them to either request a new ballot or proceed with the original one. The lawsuit argued that those who chose to file their "original ballots are entitled to a manual inspection of their ballots later," and claimed that voters were urged to cast their original ballots by poll workers rather than request a new one. In total, 4,816 votes were deemed overvotes, which would be insufficient to overcome Biden's 10,457-vote advantage.  A representative for Maricopa County stated that only "180 potential overvotes" were involved in the lawsuit, and that it would be "absurd" to assume all 180 were incorrectly counted.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Polletta|first1=Maria|last2=Oxford|first2=Andrew|date=November 9, 2020|title=Republican challenge to Maricopa County election involves fewer than 200 ballots, attorneys say|work=[[Arizona Republic]]|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/arizona/2020/11/09/arizona-election-results-maricopa-county-challenge-involves-180-ballots/6229767002/|access-date=November 11, 2020}}</ref> The Trump campaign requested that their evidence be kept secret from the public, but the judge refused to allow the secrecy.<ref name="Polletta">{{cite news|last1=Polletta|first1=Maria|date=November 10, 2020|title=Judge rejects Trump team's request for secret evidence in lawsuit over Maricopa County votes|work=[[Arizona Republic]]|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/11/10/trump-lawsuit-maricopa-county-votes-secret-evidence-kory-langhofer-thomas-liddy/6242176002/|access-date=November 12, 2020}}</ref> The Trump campaign also stated that they had video footage from within a polling area; however, such footage would be illegal if taken within 75 feet of a polling area with voters present. Thomas Liddy, a lawyer representing Maricopa County, deemed the lawsuit unnecessary, as if their claims were correct, both Biden and Trump votes would be equally affected, while [[Roopali Desai]], an attorney representing the Secretary of State, argued the lawsuit attempted to "find a problem when one does not exist".

[[Mick West]], a skeptical investigator and creator of the website ''Metabunk'', cited how the percentage of votes deemed overvotes was lower or the same percentage as the last four elections, and a considerable decrease from 2016, when 21,785 overvotes (1.4%) were cast in the presidential election in Maricopa County.<ref>{{Cite web|last=West|first=Mick|date=November 7, 2020|title=Trump Campaign Lawsuit Regarding Maricopa Overvotes (and Sharpies)|url=https://www.metabunk.org/threads/trump-campaign-lawsuit-regarding-maricopa-overvotes-and-sharpies.11447/|access-date=February 11, 2021|website=Metabunk}}</ref>

On November 10, 2020, Associate Presiding Civil Judge Daniel Kiley accepted a request from [[Snell & Wilmer]], the law firm which was representing the Trump campaign and its allies, to withdraw from the Arizona lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=David|date=November 11, 2020|title=Snell & Wilmer withdraws from election lawsuit as Trump contests Arizona results|work=|publisher=[[Reuters]]|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/snell-maricopa/snell-wilmer-withdraws-from-election-lawsuit-as-trump-contests-arizona-results-idUSL1N2HY005|access-date=November 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sherman|first1=Jon|last2=Vallejo|first2=Justin|date=November 12, 202|title=US election results – live: Trump's law firm pulls out in Arizona, amid claims president knows fight is over|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/us-election-results-news-live-biden-trump-map-b1721639.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112160412/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/us-election-results-news-live-biden-trump-map-b1721639.html |archive-date=2020-11-12 |url-access=limited |url-status=live|access-date=November 12, 2020}}</ref> On November 11, 2020, [[Arizona Attorney General]] [[Mark Brnovich]] rejected Trump's voter fraud claim during an interview with [[Fox Business]] and stated that Biden would win the state of Arizona.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|date=November 11, 2020|title=Joe Biden will win Arizona: AG Mark Brnovich|work=[[Fox Business]]|publisher=|url=https://video.foxbusiness.com/v/6209078369001/|access-date=November 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Mangan|first=Dan|date=2020-11-11|title='Very, highly unlikely' Trump wins Arizona, no evidence of fraud, Republican state attorney general says|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/11/trump-unlikely-to-beat-biden-in-arizona-no-fraud-seen-state-ag-says.html|access-date=2020-11-13|website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref> On November 13, the Trump campaign dropped their lawsuit after it became evident that the number of votes potentially to be contested would not overcome Biden's margin of victory in the state.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scannell|first1=Kara|date=November 13, 2020|title=Trump campaign drops Arizona lawsuit requesting review of ballots|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/13/politics/arizona-trump-lawsuit/index.html|access-date=|website=|publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

title: 2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
2020 United States presidential election in Arizona
added: On April 24, 2024, [[Arizona Attorney General]] [[Kris Mayes]] announced that a grand jury has [[Arizona prosecution of fake electors|indicited]] eleven fake electors and seven Trump allies, including [[Rudy Giuliani]] and [[Mark Meadows]] for their roles in overturning the results for Trump.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Billeaud |first1=Jacques |last2=Kelety |first2=Josh |last3=Cooper |first3=Jonathan J. |title=Arizona indicts 18 in case over 2020 election in Arizona, including Giuliani and Meadows |url=https://apnews.com/article/arizona-fake-electors-charges-2020-election-9da5a7e58814ed55ceea1ca55401af85 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=April 24, 2024}}</ref>
